properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued By Town Of Springside
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for Town of Springside. This advisory is for the entire community and any individuals who may access water from the Town of Springside water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2019-12-16T12:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Springside, 2019-12-01T13:39:59-06:00, 6728D031-00E4-871B-73DF-11974BD0E6AC
Area: Town of Springside
properties.Author: SK Springside

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected. Strong easterly winds gusting to 80 km/h near the Richardson Mountains combined with falling snow has result in blizzard conditions today. Snow has tapered off this afternoon, wind has weaken to 60 km/h, leading to some improvement in visibility. However, blizzard conditions will redevelop near the Richardson Mountains by Monday morning as winds increase to gusting to 100 km/h. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-02T16:11:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T00:12:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3966374648.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Drizzle Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Patchy freezing drizzle this evening. Periods of freezing drizzle, mixed with snow at times, will continue this evening. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing drizzle advisories are issued when drizzle falling in sub-zero temperatures is expected to freeze on contact, and over time create icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-02T09:19:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-01T23:29:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1215419803.2019
Area: City of Hamilton, Mississauga - Brampton, Halton Hills - Milton, Burlington - Oakville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall of 2 to 4 cm expected by Monday morning. A weak front over the Lower Mainland is giving light snow to much of the Fraser Valley. Periods of snow are expected to change to rain overnight or Monday morning as warmer air arrives. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect until 2 AM EST. A narrow band of heavier snowfall continues to affect areas east of Georgian Bay. This band should slowly weaken after midnight. A few additional centimetres of snow are possible. Hazardous travel conditions are likely under this band. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain is expected. Rain is also possible along the Fundy coast and over southeastern regions. Locations: Northern and western New Brunswick for snow; southern and eastern New Brunswick for ice pellets, freezing rain and rain. Time span: Late Monday evening until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets are forecast to begin near midnight over southern New Brunswick. Precipitation will spread across the province, reaching northern areas by noon. The precipitation may switch over to rain along the Fundy coast and southeast New Brunswick in the morning, then change back to snow. There is also a risk of freezing rain in the south during the transition between rain and snow. The snow will end overnight Tuesday night over western areas and early Wednesday morning over eastern areas. Snowfall warnings will likely be required for northwestern parts of the province, with freezing rain warnings possible for areas to the south and east. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-02T17:56:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T01:57:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4118768709.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain is expected. Rain is also possible along the Fundy coast and in the southeast. Locations: New Brunswick except for northwestern areas. Time span: Late Monday evening until early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow and ice pellets are forecast to begin near midnight over southern New Brunswick. Precipitation will spread across the province, reaching northeastern areas in the afternoon. The precipitation may switch over to rain along the Fundy coast and southeast New Brunswick in the morning, then changing back to snow. There is also a risk of freezing rain in the south during the transition between rain and snow. The snow will end overnight Tuesday night over western areas and early Wednesday morning over eastern areas. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific front will move onto the north coast tonight. Periods of snow over the North Coast inland sections including Stewart will intensify this evening to heavy snow. 15 cm snow accumulation is forecast tonight with additional 10 to 15 cm on Monday. Snow may become mixed with rain Monday afternoon then taper to a few flurries in the evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-02T16:03:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-02T00:04:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1910236758.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix is expected. Locations: central, west, north and inland regions of the south. Time span: Tuesday through Wednesday morning. Remarks: Freezing rain, at times mixed with ice pellets, is expected to begin Tuesday morning over southern Newfoundland then spread northward throughout the day. The freezing rain will transition over to rain in the south late in the day Tuesday and elsewhere Tuesday night, except for the north. In the north, a wintry mix of snow, ice pellets and freezing rain is expected to begin late in the day Tuesday and persist until Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-02T11:22:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-01T19:23:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1885717150.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow continues tonight. The snow is expected to taper off this afternoon with a few flurries and possible freezing drizzle. Near midnight heavier snow will return with up to 5 cm of snow accumulation possible. The snow is expected to end early Monday morning. Strong wind gusts up to 60 km/h and local blowing snow reducing visibilities are also possible tonight. Travel on roads will likely be very hazardous. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. There may be a significant impact on rush hour traffic in urban areas. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-02T12:25:41-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-01T20:26:41-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2202267796.2019
Area: Pickering - Oshawa - Southern Durham Region, Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update: High Water Advisory Alert Is Being Issued For The Roseau River From Gardenton To Dominion City
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City due to expected high flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by the local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-12-02T10:30:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-12-01T10:31:54-06:00, 6EC7BF5E-01F8-0B1F-FEC2-06ADC8F72AF9
Area: Roseau River from Gardenton to Dominion City
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY ISSUED FOR PRINCE GEORGE (December 1, 2019 10:00 - Prince George). The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Prince George due to high concentrations of fine particulate matter (PM2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure to fine particulate matter is of particular concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce exposure to fine particulate matter. The City of Prince Georgeâ€™s Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including back-yard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits recreational fires, use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users), and street sweeping activties (unless approved by an Authorized Person). Industry is required to follow permit requirements that are triggered during airquality advisories and are asked to reduce emissions wherever possible. Real-time airquality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-02T22:39:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-12-02T06:40:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1357834941.2019
Area: Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Strong winds are occurring in wind-prone areas, and causing localized blowing snow. The blowing snow is expected to end late Monday afternoon, but a few sites may still see some local blowing snow Monday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. A weak front over the lower mainland is giving snow to much of the Fraser Valley tonight. The highest accumulations are expected in the eastern Fraser Valley, where cool outflow winds will keep the precipitation as snow through Monday morning. Snow will change to rain by Monday afternoon. About 5 cm of snow is expected tonight with an additional 2 to 4 cm on Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, rain or ice pellets expected. Locations: Prince Edward Island Time span: Early Tuesday morning until Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, rain and ice pellets will develop early Tuesday morning and is expected to change to rain in the afternoon. Rain will persist until Wednesday morning. At this time, snow and ice pellets are most likely over western areas, rain over eastern areas and a risk of freezing rain. However, there is a lot of uncertainty in precipitation type and this forecast could change. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow with a potential prolonged period of freezing rain then changing to rain is expected. Time span: Monday morning until Wednesday morning. Locations: Nova Scotia Remarks: Snow or rain is expected to start in southwestern Nova Scotia Monday morning. Precipitation will spread very slowly northward and eastward across the province Monday and Monday night reaching northern areas of the province by early Tuesday morning. There are indications that some inland areas of the province could receive a prolonged period of freezing rain Monday night. Also some areas could get a period of heavy rain on Tuesday. It is too early to predict how much of each precipitation type will occur given uncertainty in the track of the system. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
